title: Footballer lied on insurance claim that he couldn’t work while winning league
text:
Richie Allen of Salford City celebrates after scoring a goal against Notts County in November 2015 (Picture: Getty)

A professional footballer lied that he couldn’t work after a car crash to claim an insurance payout while helping his team win the league.

Richie Allen played more than 30 matches during the 11 months he claimed to be unable with work with whiplash after being a passenger in a car crash in Preston in January 2017.

In that time he scored 17 goals for Salford FC as they won the title in the 2017-18 season to get promoted to the National League.

The now-League Two team is part-owned by former Manchester United stars including David Beckham and Ryan Giggs.

Mr Allen left Salford FC after the league triumph and played for Longridge Town FC of the North West Counties League Premier Division.

At Preston County Court on August 20, Mr Allen was ordered to pay back more than £6,000, according to leading specialist insurance law firm Horwich Farrelly.

Richie Allen of Salford City celebrates on the pitch after winning the National League North championship (Picture: Getty)

A spokesman said: ‘Footballer Richard Allen scored a spectacular own goal after a court ruled he made a dishonest claim for whiplash following a car accident.

‘In total he played more than 30 matches after the accident disproving his claim that he was injured.

‘When Horwich Farrelly exposed that Allen had indeed been playing in football matches despite saying he was injured, his defence was that he was able to play because he was self-medicating with illegally purchased steroids in order to hide his injuries as he had no other means of income besides football.

‘Despite these claims Horwich Farrelly pushed for the case to go to court where the judge found Allen fundamentally dishonest and ordered him to pay costs of over £6,000.’

It is reported Mr Allen won’t face criminal charges.

description: Richie Allen, 37, helped Salford City FC win the league while claiming he was unable to work after a car crash.
